text: Wallace and Poot discover Brandon's murdered and mutilated body displayed publicly near Wallace's squatter apartment.
Wallace is deeply disturbed and anguished after seeing Brandon's mutilated corpse, affecting his demeanor.
D'Angelo discusses his relationship with Shardene, revealing his cynical view that all women, including his other girlfriend Donette, ultimately have a 'cost'.
D'Angelo dismisses Wallace's distress over Brandon's murder, unsympathetically reminding him that killing is an expected part of 'the game' in their line of work.
Stringer Bell informs D'Angelo that arrangements are being made by the organization to secure Bodie Broadus's release from custody following his recent arrests.
At a court hearing, Barksdale lawyer Maurice Levy successfully argues for Bodie's release by fabricating a defense, resulting in probation instead of continued detention.
Detectives Herc and Carver, attempting to re-arrest Bodie assuming he escaped again, are surprised to find he has already been legally released through Levy's intervention.
Avon Barksdale, Stringer Bell, and Stinkum visit the Pit to deliver reward money to D'Angelo and Wallace for their role in locating Brandon.
During the reward delivery, Avon explicitly confirms to D'Angelo that Wee-Bey Brice and Marquis 'Bird' Hilton tortured and killed Brandon.
D'Angelo assures Stringer Bell that there are no informants ('snitches') within his Pit crew.
Avon promises D'Angelo that continued good performance managing the Pit will soon earn him 'points on the package' (a percentage of the drug profits).
D'Angelo discovers his lookout Cassandra and dealer Sterling have been skimming small amounts from the drug count to sell independently.
To handle the internal theft quietly and protect Cassandra and Sterling, D'Angelo reassigns them elsewhere, informing only Wallace of the situation.
With Johnny Weeks released from medical care after his beating, he and Bubbles return to the streets together.
Bubbles and Johnny run a scam stealing copper pipes from vacant buildings and selling them to a contractor for drug money.
While attempting to steal back the same copper pipes they just sold to the contractor, Johnny Weeks is arrested by police.
Major Rawls pressures McNulty again, demanding the Barksdale investigation be concluded within one week.
Under pressure from Rawls, Sgt. Landsman orders Bunk Moreland to prepare charges against the Barksdales based on the old, potentially linked homicide cases (like Kresson's).
McNulty, Greggs, and Freamon strongly object to filing premature charges, arguing it will alert the Barksdales and sabotage the ongoing wiretap investigation.
Lt. Daniels fails to change Rawls' mind but successfully persuades Dep. Comm. Burrell to overrule Rawls, allowing the wiretap investigation to continue without filing immediate charges.
Angered by Burrell's intervention, Rawls instructs his mole, Detective Santangelo, to intensify efforts to find compromising information on McNulty.
With the payphone wiretaps now active, Freamon notes a significant volume of pager activity occurred the night Brandon was presumably captured and killed.
The legal requirement to monitor live wiretap calls means long surveillance shifts; Herc expresses dismay at the tedious work involved.
Freamon expresses frustration at the lack of enthusiasm from colleagues like Herc for the wiretap work, questioning their commitment to building the case.
Freamon uses a tapped call where Stinkum chastises Bodie for using names on the phone as an example of legally 'pertinent' evidence establishing conspiracy, even without direct drug talk.
Prez Pryzbylewski demonstrates unexpected aptitude and keen interest in meticulously logging and analyzing the wiretap data.
Impressed by Prez's dedication and recognizing the need, Lt. Daniels approves his request for additional filing cabinets to better organize the growing wiretap intelligence.
Daniels confronts Detective Polk for arriving at work drunk, giving him an ultimatum: sober up for duty or check into medical for alcohol treatment; Polk chooses medical leave.
McNulty discusses Brandon's murder with the assigned Homicide detectives (Holley and Norris), confirming the strong suspicion of a Barksdale connection.
McNulty receives a call from Omar while watching his sons and, lacking childcare options, is forced to take them along to meet Omar at the city morgue.
At the morgue, McNulty's young sons inadvertently overhear Omar Little's anguished screams upon viewing Brandon's tortured body.
Omar visits the Barksdale detail office, where the team confirms the high pager activity logged the previous night corresponds precisely to Brandon's abduction and murder.

McNulty expresses intense frustration that despite having the pager data in real-time, they lacked the crucial audio context (from wiretaps) to understand the situation and potentially intervene before Brandon's death.
Investigating Brandon's abduction, Freamon and McNulty interview the owner of the arcade where Brandon was spotted; Freamon identifies the nearby payphone used to page D'Angelo.
Seeking revenge for Brandon's brutal murder, Omar Little formally offers to testify against Barksdale soldier Marquis 'Bird' Hilton for the earlier murder of witness William Gant.
The episode concludes visually with the graphic police photographs of Brandon's tortured and mutilated corpse placed prominently on Lt. Daniels' desk.
